Satya Nadellaの「全方位外交」とハイパースケーラーの冷徹な計算

Satya Nadellaのインタビューを読み解き、OpenAIへの依存を脱して全方位的な「AIインフラ」として君臨しようとするマイクロソフトの冷徹なグランドストラテジーを分析する

LLM
Podcast
Author

Junichiro Iwasawa

Published

November 20, 2025

Olmo 3: Advancing Open-Source Reasoning Models

The field of artificial intelligence is rapidly evolving, with a constant stream of new models and advancements. Among the most significant developments are those that prioritize openness, allowing researchers and developers worldwide to build upon and scrutinize the technology. In this spirit, the Allen Institute for AI (Ai2) has released Olmo 3, a new family of language models designed to be fully open and highly competitive, particularly in the domain of reasoning.

This release marks a pivotal moment for Ai2 and the Olmo project, introducing models that are not mere replications of older architectures but are designed to push the boundaries of what’s possible with open-source AI. The Olmo 3 family includes 7 billion (7B) and 32 billion (32B) parameter models, each with distinct strengths and intended applications.

A Foundation of Openness and Performance

A core principle behind the Olmo project is the belief that open-source models must be performant to be viable. Olmo 3 directly addresses this by offering:

  1. The best 32B base model: In a landscape where larger base models have seen fewer open releases, the Olmo 3 32B base model provides a crucial, high-performance starting point for various applications, especially those requiring complex reasoning.
  2. Leading 7B Western-developed models: The 7B models in the Olmo 3 family are positioned as the best open-source options developed by Western organizations, offering strong capabilities in reasoning and instruction following.
  3. The first truly open 32B+ reasoning model: This release pioneers a fully open, large-scale model specifically engineered for reasoning tasks, a critical area for advanced AI applications.

Crucially, all Olmo 3 models come with comprehensive resources, including training data, code, intermediate checkpoints, training logs, and detailed technical reports. This level of transparency is essential for fostering trust, enabling replication, and accelerating research within the AI community.

The “Model Flow”: A Lifecycle of Innovation

Ai2 has introduced the concept of a “Model Flow” to describe the lifecycle of creating and refining these models. This encompasses the base models and a variety of post-training checkpoints tailored for different needs:

  • Instruct Models: These are designed for low-latency, high-utility tasks, evolving from Ai2’s previous Tülu 3 pipeline. They aim to be a significant upgrade over existing 7B models, providing a reliable option for enterprises seeking trusted AI solutions.
  • Think Models: These are the flagship reasoning models, with extensive effort dedicated to their development. The Olmo 3 Think models, especially the 32B version, have undergone rigorous training, including the creation of a specialized reasoning dataset (Dolci-Think-SFT) and advanced fine-tuning techniques like Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) and Reinforcement Learning with Verbalized Rewards (RLVR). These models achieve performance close to leading proprietary models on challenging benchmarks like AIME and GPQA.
  • RL Zero Models: Inspired by recent advancements, Ai2 is exploring the potential of starting with Reinforcement Learning (RL) directly on base models, rather than relying solely on supervised fine-tuning. They have released datasets and checkpoints demonstrating RL Zero performance on math, code, and chat tasks, opening new avenues for research into the fundamental capabilities of AI models and potential issues like data contamination.

A Commitment to Openness and the Future

The release of Olmo 3 represents a massive undertaking by Ai2, involving a large team of researchers and contributors. The project aims to provide the AI community with powerful, transparent tools that can accelerate progress in safe and beneficial AI development.

Looking ahead, Ai2 sees “thinking” and “instruct” capabilities as existing on a spectrum. Future work will focus on optimizing this trade-off, creating models that balance performance with latency and throughput needs for diverse use cases. Planned developments include Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models, enhanced character training, and specialized models for internal use, all contributing to Ai2’s broader ATOM project goals.

The Olmo 3 release is more than just new models; it’s a reaffirmation of the power of open collaboration in advancing artificial intelligence. By providing cutting-edge, fully transparent tools, Ai2 empowers the global community to explore, build, and innovate responsibly.
